body:
I'd not worry about v1 listing at all, as it only adds more testing, and even third party stores all seem to do v2. V2 scales better.

Bear in mind multipart upload timestamps are set to when an upload starts, not when it finishes; if you are polling for changes that can catch you out
This pull-request depends on PR NIFI-7099. If NIFI-7099 is merge I will update this PR.
Looks good to me too. Thanks for the PR @bbende! Thanks for the review @kevdoran! This has been merged to master.
Thanks Pierre. Looks good to me. +1, merging.
Building locally on Java 11 to verify.
Thanks for fixing this @mcgilman! Code looks correct. Tested and verified behavior before and after the fix. +1 merging to master.
Verified the full build locally on Java 11. The Travis thing was a false positive. Merging.

Thanks for submitting this. Do we know why OkHttp can't just use the existing trust factory? At first glance, this looks like code that we have in other locations in the codebase to craft this object.

No, @jfrazee, the issue is that "," will return valid, and never be passed to the empty validator, or any validator you have specified.

This PR changes it so that it treats ",", which splits to a 0 length array ( IE Nothing to validate ) as if it returned nothing
In other words, even if you had trim entries, and exclude empties, that is not honored in the case of ",", because that code executes inside the for loop of split results.
I just wanted to confirm that you're leaving " , " (with spaces) to be handled inside the loop according to the the trim and exclude?

I've check the travis-ci check.
It has nothing to do with my change.
The error was: "Connect to maven-central.storage-download.googleapis.com:443 ... failed: Connection timed out"

I'll write an explicit test for that " , ".  I just handled the empty list, so if that did not produce an empty list before, it won't change the behavior.  If it _did_ produce and empty list before, then yes, it will not be not valid
Ok, so " , " evaluates to a list of two, so this fix will not effect it

part of the issue here is our testing framework.  we can't tell in the tests if something is not valid because of the validator or because of other reasons.  IE> if the validator for items was called.
I'm going to create a jira for that
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-7109
Reviewing...
I used Google Chrome Developer Tools to simulate a slow connection and verified that the buttons are disabled during the API call. Ran `contrib-check` and all tests pass. +1, merging.
TYSM @andy

OkHttp suggests we rely on the system trust factory, per the docs:  https://square.github.io/okhttp/4.x/okhttp/okhttp3/-ok-http-client/-builder/ssl-socket-factory/

For our uses in this processor, I'm not sure there is another way to supply the trust store certs from the SSL context service to the HTTP client.  Do you know of any, or do you think there's a better approach?
Reviewing...
Thanks Pierre. This looks good. Merging.
Thanks Drew, this is really helpful.
Thanks Drew.

It looks like we have similar/identical code for constructing these objects in [`OkHttpReplicationClient`](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/master/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-framework-bundle/nifi-framework/nifi-framework-cluster/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/cluster/coordination/http/replication/okhttp/OkHttpReplicationClient.java#L357) and [`InvokeHttp`](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/master/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-standard-bundle/nifi-standard-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/processors/standard/InvokeHTTP.java#L692) among others. I think as this is becoming a common need, we should provide a utility method to wrap this logic and provide it in a class like [`KeyStoreUtils`](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/master/nifi-commons/nifi-security-utils/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/security/util/KeyStoreUtils.java#L33) in `nifi-security-utils` module.
I think you're right.  I'll refactor those bits.
Thanks for the improvement @trucemop - this looks good to me and is now merged into master.
I just gave it a try and it LGTM as well. @markap14 do you want to have a look or are you happy with me merging it into master?
Hi, just bumping this one, in case someone can take a look at it.
+1 LGTM, ran contrib-check and tried on a live NiFi instance, verified the additional fields are present and correct. Thanks for the improvement! Merging to master

Can you please add unit test(s) for your changes? Also, if this changes current behavior we need to see what the impact is with respect to backwards compatibility (i.e. if I have an existing flow then I upgrade to a version of NiFi that has this PR in it, does my original flow act the same?)

Following on from previous PR #4040 
@alopresto I believe this refactors the SSL context and trust manager calls you mentioned.
This fix changes the default certificate validity period to one accepted by [macOS 10.15 Catalina](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT210176).
+1 LGTM, ran contrib-check and on a live NiFi instance after bumping the Calcite version to 1.21. Everything ran well, thanks for the improvement! Merging to master
PR built and tested with Single Node in a 3 node cluster. +1
Merged into master, thanks @markap14
LGTM, +1, merged to master, thanks @woutifier-t

Thanks @jsferner - this PR is really well put together! Code is well written and easy to follow. The additional commits in the PR made it really easy to understand how to test and verify behavior. +1 merged to master

I've added a Unit Test for ResultSetRecordSet with and without a given schema.
With a given schema it is possible to extract the correct Data Type from Arrays instead of fallback to String Type when schema is inferred.
Let's see if Travis is happier with this...

This does solve the dependency issue but the Java 11 build fails on some tests. Using the Travis OpenJDK 11.0.2_9 instead of AdoptOpenJDK 11.0.4_11 could be the reason... @jtstorck - does it sound familiar?
+1 LGTM (Travis failures are unrelated), ran contrib-check, everything looks good. Thanks for the improvement! Merging to master
Sorry for the force-push override of the commit, but with the merge conflict it was just easier. All changes should be the same except now there are no changes to StandardProcessGroup

So I'm breaking a test case in TestConvertRecord that checks to see if the flow file was modified when being routed to failure. Adding attributes creates a new flow file so while the contents haven't changed the object isn't the same.
I can change the check to compare the contents of the flow file instead since that's really what matters.

It would potentially break workflows which convert milliseconds into microseconds manually before sending to kudu today.

We could release note it, or I could specially handling long RecordFieldTypes to keep treating them as micros. We could also put the special micros handling behind a configuration flag. I suspect the least surprising behavior is to treat all numerical values as milliseconds though.
@zorel Is this still an issue for you? If so we should file a jira.

> @zorel Is this still an issue for you? If so we should file a jira.

Yeah, I'm not part of the team anymore, but it seems they still have the problem, every week. I'll see with them if/when they upgrade to 1.10 to see if it still happens. Thanks
Reviewing...
Reviewing...

I'm getting a lot of compilation errors on Java 8. I see some language constructs that weren't introduced until Java 9, like `Set.of()`. I started fixing them but there are more than I anticipated. Can you please provide a new commit which also builds on Java 8?
@joewitt, can you clarify what this change means for contributors?  I test my pr's in my personal travis, will this work the same way?
Closing manually... I didn't correctly change the commit message... It's merged to master, thanks @turcsanyip
I rebased onto the latest master changes.
I rebased onto the latest master changes.

If adopted it means we'd no longer utilize travis-ci for build verification to ease PR handling process but would instead use github actions/ci processes.  You could certainly still use whatever personal process you like.  You'd have to maintain your own travis config in your repo though.
Will github actions just work in our forks?  or is there some kind of opt-in signup that we need to have done?

I believe it will as that is how I'm currently testing this PR but could be wrong.  In terms of the community managed repo it will run on any pull request or update to a pull request or as things land on master (just like travis is supposed to).

Hi @mail2atulm - thanks for the contribution. Is there a JIRA associated to this pull request? If not, can you create one to explain the improvement and use case? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI
Merging to master, thanks for this first contribution @karthik-kadajji
Merged to master, thanks @granthenke
@granthenke - can you rebase now that I merged #4053?
I will rebase this after #4063 gets in.
Merged to master, thanks @granthenke

LGTM.

- I updated the [Migration Guidance page](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NIFI/Migration+Guidance) to reflect this change
- merged this PR into master

Thanks @granthenke
@pvillard31 yes there is a JIRA. Ticket number: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-7098
Reviewed and merged.
Reviewed and ran with full tests and contrib-check on both Java 8 and Java 11. Everything succeeded.

Thank you @pvillard31 for your feedback!

We fix the style problem and the `mvn clean install -Pcontrib-check` completed successfully.
How can I test this?  I don't see any indication of actions running or anything.  Is there something that should be there to see?

Im guessing all of us are new to the github actions stuff.  Please read/review the links provided in the JIRA.  I am testing and learning this by pushing to my own fork and evaluating.  This PR is just part of an early attempt to see how it will impact in the nifi repo.
if you want to watch progress as I'm learning this thing https://github.com/joewitt/nifi/actions
Thanks @joewitt, this is great.  It is an interesting case as to how you would do a PR *on actions* and have them reviewed though ;)

Hi, any progress updates on this?
I could really use a getSMBfile (as well as a listSMBfile and fetchSMBfile) processor
Late to the game, but thanks for making this doc update @alopresto !
Hello Mr. @pvillard31. When CI/CD phase occur erros by others codes, i will need do something ?
No, as long as one of the Java 8 builds is working it should be good. The Travis builds are not reliable at the moment and we're working on this.
Pushed commits that address review comments from @alopresto
Reviewing...
Could you add a unit test or update the integration tests to confirm it fixes https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-6293 ?

Made the changes requested. Also noticed some windows line encoding weirdness when I saved the file. Weird because I'm doing this on a Mac. So two separate commits. Feel free to drop the dos2unix one.
@MikeThomsen the original cause of the jira was that the test actually failed on line 191 assertion (not just because they were swapped).
@joewitt I tried running it a few times, and couldn't replicate the failure. Do you have any idea what configuration it was running on when it failed?
a machine I do builds on all the time.  i've only seen failures in the solr tests rarely.  But that it can fail in the way it did suggests there is some timing thing we need to sort out.

Ok. I'll look at the query. I think you said it mysteriously craps the bed in those cases and goes from finding at least some documents to finding none. If that be the case, it could be something wonky with the `commit()` call fully refreshing the searchers in embedded mode.

* Looked over the solrconf, looks good. It's storing everything in memory so there are no FS artifacts to worry about between runs.
* Query is super simple: `*:*` which is a wildcard to return everything.
* Nothing obvious that is related to file system-related issues.

If you have any stacktraces, that would be great. Otherwise, we might have to mark this with the ignore annotation and wait until there's a stacktrace from one of your builds.
Rebased with master and moved WritesAttributes out of the abstract class for now.
+1, merged to master, thanks @taz1988 for your contribution!
@bahlulh Would you take a look at and vote on this PR? This has been open  quite long.

There is no stack trace of importance here because what failed was the assertion.  It got nothing but expected 10 things.

We have provenance tests which require waiting a bit to let indexing occur before attempting the query.  It 'seems like' this could be a similar problem here.  Do you agree?  If so rather than ignoring could we try checking if results are there yet and if not try again in a few seconds and if not done within some time cause the test to timeout instead?
would love to see @markap14 get some eyes on here but it looks good.  I'm just not quite comfortable merging myself as I dont feel confident enough in the EL world

Hello.  This is an interesting PR/good idea.  I wonder though if this should just be a partitioning strategy in PartitionRecord.  If we keep it separate like this we might want to go with a more specific name than DistributeRecord as we might want different distribution options and this one seems to be pretty specific to weighted distribution using one or more hashing functions.  Maybe then the name should be 'WeightedRecordDistribution'

In any case how about squashing the commits and rebasing to master and pushing the forced PR.  This will let the new CI processes run against the PR.
@gardellajuanpablo given #4002 and its having been merged can we close this one out?

It's been a few years since I last really used Solr, but the `commit()` there is a blocking call that forces a flush to the Lucene indexes and rewarms the "searchers" which are the Java objects that actually execute the queries. So this makes no sense to me because of that and the fact that queries are not asynchronous. So there should be no concept of "waiting for the results" in this use case.

@bbende @ijokarumawak thoughts?

> @gardellajuanpablo given #4002 and its having been merged can we close this one out?

yes, we can close this PR.

This really should have had some doc around the fact that the existing properties are ignored if the CS is set, I wrote up [NIFI-7189](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-7189) as an improvement Jira.
Also there are some logic errors in there, once a failure happens you have to restart the CS, will try to characterize and write a Jira
